title: Split Version 1 and Version 2 into separate standalone frontend deployments

requirements.summary: Remove in-app version selection and make each deployment serve its version from root route ('/') with its own URL.
acceptanceCriteria: There is no user-facing version-selection screen required to access Version 1 vs Version 2 (each version is accessed by its own deployment URL).
Version 1 loads directly at its own URL on '/' (no need to visit '/v1' first).
Version 2 loads directly at its own URL on '/' (no need to visit '/v2' first).
Both URLs can be opened simultaneously in two browser tabs/windows and function independently.

file_operations.description: Replace the current manual routing (/, /v1, /v2, etc.) with a standalone app router: '/' renders the question screen for the configured version, and '/success' renders the existing success screen; remove all version-select flow and any '/v1' or '/v2' route handling so each deployment operates independently at its own URL.
Remove the version selection screen implementation to ensure there is no user-facing version-selection entry flow in the standalone deployments.

requirements.summary: Preserve all existing behaviors and exact texts per version, including the Yes navigation and evasive No behavior.
acceptanceCriteria: In the Version 1 deployment, the question screen heading is exactly: "Cia will you be mine forever or will stay for lifetime? ‚ù§Ô∏è".
In the Version 2 deployment, the question screen heading is exactly: "Khusnul will you be mine forever or will stay for lifetime? ‚ù§Ô∏è".
In both deployments, clicking/tapping "Yes üíñ" shows the existing success screen with the exact existing success text/subtext and existing heart/confetti-style animation.
In both deployments, the "No üíî" button remains evasive with the same fixed-position random movement rules and click/tap safety behavior as currently implemented.

file_operations.description: Add a small build-time configuration module that determines which standalone variant is being built (v1 vs v2) based on a build-time setting (e.g., a Vite environment value), and exposes the exact required heading text for the chosen variant.

Wire the question screen heading to the build-time variant configuration so Version 1 and Version 2 show the exact required heading texts, while preserving existing behavior: "Yes üíñ" navigates to '/success' and the existing SuccessScreen/QuestionScreen logic (including evasive No behavior) remains unchanged.

Ensure the screen remains behavior-identical after the routing changes (no changes to the evasive No mechanics and safety handling; keep the same button labels and positioning behavior), limiting any edits to compatibility with the new root-route setup.

requirements.summary: Add build/deploy configuration so two distinct frontend artifacts (v1 and v2) can be built and deployed from the same repo without code edits.
acceptanceCriteria: There is a documented, repeatable way to build/deploy Version 1 and Version 2 as separate standalone frontends producing two different published URLs.
Switching between Version 1 and Version 2 for deployment is controlled via configuration (e.g., build-time setting) rather than editing source files each time.

file_operations.description: Create a Version 1 build configuration file defining the build-time setting used by the app variant module (e.g., a Vite env value indicating variant = v1).
Create a Version 2 build configuration file defining the build-time setting used by the app variant module (e.g., a Vite env value indicating variant = v2).

Document the repeatable process to build and deploy two separate standalone frontends (v1 and v2) from the same repo using build-time configuration (e.g., building with two different modes), including how each produces a distinct published URL with root route '/'.
Add an optional helper script that runs the Version 1 build using configuration (no source edits) and outputs a distinct artifact directory suitable for deploying as its own URL.
Add an optional helper script that runs the Version 2 build using configuration (no source edits) and outputs a distinct artifact directory suitable for deploying as its own URL.
